extra_args.description: A space separated string of additional commands that can be applied to the Bundler command. Refer to the Bundler documentation for more information

state.description:
Default: present

The desired state of the Gem bundle. C(latest) updates gems to the most recent, acceptable version

clean.description:
Default: no

Only applies if state is C(present). If set removes any gems on the target host that are not in the gemfile

binstub_directory.description: Only applies if state is C(present). Specifies the directory to install any gem bins files to. When executed the bin files will run within the context of the Gemfile and fail if any required gem dependencies are not installed. If C(chdir) is set then this path is relative to C(chdir)

exclude_groups.description: A list of Gemfile groups to exclude during operations. This only applies when state is C(present). Bundler considers this a 'remembered' property for the Gemfile and will automatically exclude groups in future operations even if C(exclude_groups) is not set

local.description:
Default: no

If set only installs gems from the cache on the target host

gem_path.description:
Default: RubyGems gem paths

Only applies if state is C(present). Specifies the directory to install the gems into. If C(chdir) is set then this path is relative to C(chdir)

urpmi.description: Manages packages with I(urpmi) (such as for Mageia or Mandriva)

force.description:
Default: True

Assume "yes" is the answer to any question urpmi has to ask. Corresponds to the C(--force) option for I(urpmi).

state.description:
Default: present

Indicates the desired package state

update_cache.description: update the package database first C(urpmi.update -a).

pkg.description: name of package to install, upgrade or remove.

no-recommends.description:
Default: True

Corresponds to the C(--no-recommends) option for I(urpmi).

os_flavor_facts.description: Retrieve facts about available OpenStack instance flavors. By default, facts about ALL flavors are retrieved. Filters can be applied to get facts for only matching flavors. For example, you can filter on the amount of RAM available to the flavor, or the number of virtual CPUs available to the flavor, or both. When specifying multiple filters, *ALL* filters must match on a flavor before that flavor is returned as a fact.

vcpus.description: A string used for filtering flavors based on the number of virtual CPUs desired. Format is the same as the I(ram) parameter.

ram.description:
A string used for filtering flavors based on the amount of RAM (in MB) desired. This string accepts the following special values: 'MIN' (return flavors with the minimum amount of RAM), and 'MAX' (return flavors with the maximum amount of RAM).
A specific amount of RAM may also be specified. Any flavors with this exact amount of RAM will be returned.
A range of acceptable RAM may be given using a special syntax. Simply prefix the amount of RAM with one of these acceptable range values: '<', '>', '<=', '>='. These values represent less than, greater than, less than or equal to, and greater than or equal to, respectively.

limit.description:
Default: None

Limits the number of flavors returned. All matching flavors are returned by default.

name.description:
Default: None

A flavor name. Cannot be used with I(ram) or I(vcpus).

azure_rm_storageaccount_facts.description: Get facts for one storage account or all storage accounts within a resource group.

name.description: Only show results for a specific account.

resource_group.description: Limit results to a resource group. Required when filtering by name.

tags.description: Limit results by providing a list of tags. Format tags as 'key' or 'key:value'.

docker_login.description:
Provides functionality similar to the "docker login" command.
Authenticate with a docker registry and add the credentials to your local Docker config file. Adding the credentials to the config files allows future connections to the registry using tools such as Ansible's Docker modules, the Docker CLI and docker-py without needing to provide credentials.
Running in check mode will perform the authentication without updating the config file.

username.description: The username for the registry account

reauth.description: Refresh exiting authentication found in the configuration file.

url.description:
Default: https://index.docker.io/v1/

The registry URL.

config_path.description:
Default: ~/.docker/config.json

Custom path to the Docker CLI configuration file.

dockercfg_path.description:
Default: ~/.docker/config.json

Custom path to the Docker CLI configuration file.

self.config_path.description:
Default: ~/.docker/config.json

Custom path to the Docker CLI configuration file.

password.description: The plaintext password for the registry account

email.description:
Default: None

The email address for the registry account. NOTE: private registries may not require this, but Docker Hub requires it.

reauthorize.description: Refresh exiting authentication found in the configuration file.

vmware_vm_facts.description: Return basic facts pertaining to a vSphere virtual machine guest

gitlab_user.description:
When the user does not exists in Gitlab, it will be created.
When the user does exists and state=absent, the user will be deleted.
When changes are made to user, the user will be updated.

username.description: The username of the user.

verify_ssl.description:
Default: True

When using https if SSL certificate needs to be verified.

group.description: Add user as an member to this group.

name.description: Name of the user you want to create

login_user.description: Gitlab user name.

server_url.description: Url of Gitlab server, with protocol (http or https).

access_level.description:
The access level to the group. One of the following can be used.
guest
reporter
developer
master
owner

state.description:
Default: present

create or delete group.
Possible values are present and absent.

login_password.description: Gitlab password for login_user

password.description: The password of the user.

validate_certs.description:
Default: True

When using https if SSL certificate needs to be verified.

email.description: The email that belongs to the user.

state.description:
Default: present

Should the resource be present or absent.

name.description: Role Name

cluster_name.description: The name of the cluster that will be created

enable_ha.description: If set to True will enable HA when the cluster is created.

enable_drs.description: If set to True will enable DRS when the cluster is created.

datacenter_name.description: The name of the datacenter the cluster will be created in.

enable_vsan.description: If set to True will enable vSAN when the cluster is created.

ec2_remote_facts.description: Gather facts about ec2 instances in AWS

filters.description: A dict of filters to apply. Each dict item consists of a filter key and a filter value. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_DescribeInstances.html) for possible filters.

os_keypair.description: Add or Remove key pair from OpenStack

public_key.description:
Default: None

The public key that would be uploaded to nova and injected into VMs upon creation.

state.description:
Default: present

Should the resource be present or absent.

public_key_file.description:
Default: None

Path to local file containing ssh public key. Mutually exclusive with public_key.

name.description:
Default: None

Name that has to be given to the key pair

region_name.description:
Default: None

Name of the region

enable_dhcp.description:
Default: True

Whether DHCP should be enabled for this subnet.

tenant_name.description:
Default: None

The name of the tenant for whom the subnet should be created

dns_nameservers.description:
Default: None

DNS nameservers for this subnet, comma-separated

login_tenant_name.description:
Default: True

The tenant name of the login user

state.description:
Default: present

Indicate desired state of the resource

allocation_pool_start.description:
Default: None

From the subnet pool the starting address from which the IP should be allocated

auth_url.description:
Default: http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/

The keystone URL for authentication

login_password.description:
Default: True

Password of login user

login_username.description:
Default: admin

login username to authenticate to keystone

gateway_ip.description:
Default: None

The ip that would be assigned to the gateway for this subnet

cidr.description:
Default: None

The CIDR representation of the subnet that should be assigned to the subnet

network_name.description:
Default: None

Name of the network to which the subnet should be attached

ip_version.description:
Default: 4

The IP version of the subnet 4 or 6

allocation_pool_end.description:
Default: None

From the subnet pool the last IP that should be assigned to the virtual machines

name.description:
Default: None

The name of the subnet that should be created

ec2_vpc_route_table_facts.description: Gather facts about ec2 VPC route tables in AWS

filters.description: A dict of filters to apply. Each dict item consists of a filter key and a filter value. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_DescribeRouteTables.html) for possible filters.

eos_config.description: Arista EOS configurations use a simple block indent file sytanx for segementing configuration into sections.  This module provides an implementation for working with eos configuration sections in a deterministic way.  This module works with either CLI or eapi transports.

force.description: The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.

after.description: The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a changed needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines.description: The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

replace.description:
Default: line

Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct

parents.description: The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

config.description: The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuruation to use as the base config for comparision.

match.description:
Default: line

Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  Finally if match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.

before.description: The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system

eos_template.description: Manages network device configurations over SSH or eAPI.  This module allows implementors to work with the device running-config.  It provides a way to push a set of commands onto a network device by evaluting the current running-config and only pushing configuration commands that are not already configured.  The config source can be a set of commands or a template.

src.description: The path to the config source.  The source can be either a file with config or a template that will be merged during runtime.  By default the task will search for the source file in role or playbook root folder in templates directory.

force.description: The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.

backup.description: When this argument is configured true, the module will backup the running-config from the node prior to making any changes. The backup file will be written to backup_{{ hostname }} in the root of the playbook directory.

replace.description: This argument will cause the provided configuration to be replaced on the destination node.   The use of the replace argument will always cause the task to set changed to true and will implies I(force) is true.  This argument is only valid with I(transport) is eapi.

include_defaults.description: By default when the M(eos_template) connects to the remote device to retrieve the configuration it will issue the `show running-config` command.  If this option is set to True then the issued command will be `show running-config all`

config.description: The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuruation to use as the base config for comparision.

known_hosts.description: The M(known_hosts) module lets you add or remove a host from the C(known_hosts) file. This is useful if you're going to want to use the M(git) module over ssh, for example. If you have a very large number of host keys to manage, you will find the M(template) module more useful.

host.description: The host to add or remove (must match a host specified in key)

path.description:
Default: (homedir)+/.ssh/known_hosts

The known_hosts file to edit

state.description:
Default: present

I(present) to add the host, I(absent) to remove it.

name.description: The host to add or remove (must match a host specified in key)

key.description: The SSH public host key, as a string (required if state=present, optional when state=absent, in which case all keys for the host are removed)

snmp_facts.description: Retrieve facts for a device using SNMP, the facts will be inserted to the ansible_facts key.

username.description: Username for SNMPv3, required if version is v3

privacy.description: Encryption algoritm, required if level is authPriv

level.description: Authentication level, required if version is v3

community.description: The SNMP community string, required if version is v2/v2c

authkey.description: Authentication key, required if version is v3

host.description: Set to target snmp server (normally {{inventory_hostname}})

version.description: SNMP Version to use, v2/v2c or v3

integrity.description: Hashing algoritm, required if version is v3

privkey.description: Encryption key, required if version is authPriv

setup.description: This module is automatically called by playbooks to gather useful variables about remote hosts that can be used in playbooks. It can also be executed directly by C(/usr/bin/ansible) to check what variables are available to a host. Ansible provides many I(facts) about the system, automatically.

filter.description:
Default: *

if supplied, only return facts that match this shell-style (fnmatch) wildcard.

gather_subset.description:
Default: all

if supplied, restrict the additional facts collected to the given subset. Possible values: all, hardware, network, virtual, ohai, and facter Can specify a list of values to specify a larger subset. Values can also be used with an initial C(!) to specify that that specific subset should not be collected.  For instance: !hardware, !network, !virtual, !ohai, !facter.  Note that a few facts are always collected.  Use the filter parameter if you do not want to display those.

fact_path.description:
Default: /etc/ansible/facts.d

path used for local ansible facts (*.fact) - files in this dir will be run (if executable) and their results be added to ansible_local facts if a file is not executable it is read. Check notes for Windows options. (from 2.1 on) File/results format can be json or ini-format

cs_instance.description: Deploy, start, update, scale, restart, restore, stop and destroy instances.

domain.description: Domain the instance is related to.

force.description: Force stop/start the instance if required to apply changes, otherwise a running instance will not be changed.

disk_offering.description: Name of the disk offering to be used.

keyboard.description: Keyboard device type for the instance.

user_data.description:
Optional data (ASCII) that can be sent to the instance upon a successful deployment.
The data will be automatically base64 encoded.
Consider switching to HTTP_POST by using C(CLOUDSTACK_METHOD=post) to increase the HTTP_GET size limit of 2KB to 32 KB.

root_disk_size.description: Root disk size in GByte required if deploying instance with KVM hypervisor and want resize the root disk size at startup (need CloudStack >= 4.4, cloud-initramfs-growroot installed and enabled in the template)

iso_filter.description:
Default: executable

Name of the filter used to search for the template or iso.
Used for params C(iso) or C(template) on C(state=present).

tag.description:
List of tags. Tags are a list of dictionaries having keys C(key) and C(value).
If you want to delete all tags, set a empty list e.g. C(tags: []).

cpu_speed.description: The clock speed/shares allocated to the instance, used with custom service offerings

ip6_address.description: IPv6 address for default instance's network.

networks.description: List of networks to use for the new instance.

security_groups.description: List of security groups the instance to be applied to.

group.description: Group in where the new instance should be in.

network.description: List of networks to use for the new instance.

zone.description:
Name of the zone in which the instance shoud be deployed.
If not set, default zone is used.

state.description:
Default: present

State of the instance.

template.description:
Name or id of the template to be used for creating the new instance.
Required when using C(state=present).
Mutually exclusive with C(ISO) option.

memory.description: The memory allocated to the instance, used with custom service offerings

iso.description:
Name or id of the ISO to be used for creating the new instance.
Required when using C(state=present).
Mutually exclusive with C(template) option.

template_filter.description:
Default: executable

Name of the filter used to search for the template or iso.
Used for params C(iso) or C(template) on C(state=present).

ip_to_network.description:
List of mappings in the form {'network': NetworkName, 'ip': 1.2.3.4}
Mutually exclusive with C(networks) option.

tags.description:
List of tags. Tags are a list of dictionaries having keys C(key) and C(value).
If you want to delete all tags, set a empty list e.g. C(tags: []).

ssh_key.description: Name of the SSH key to be deployed on the new instance.

affinity_group.description: Affinity groups names to be applied to the new instance.

display_name.description:
Custom display name of the instances.
Display name will be set to C(name) if not specified.
Either C(name) or C(display_name) is required.

service_offering.description:
Name or id of the service offering of the new instance.
If not set, first found service offering is used.

ip_address.description: IPv4 address for default instance's network during creation.

account.description: Account the instance is related to.

disk_size.description: Disk size in GByte required if deploying instance from ISO.

name.description:
Host name of the instance. C(name) can only contain ASCII letters.
Name will be generated (UUID) by CloudStack if not specified and can not be changed afterwards.
Either C(name) or C(display_name) is required.

hypervisor.description:
Name the hypervisor to be used for creating the new instance.
Relevant when using C(state=present), but only considered if not set on ISO/template.
If not set or found on ISO/template, first found hypervisor will be used.

ip_to_networks.description:
List of mappings in the form {'network': NetworkName, 'ip': 1.2.3.4}
Mutually exclusive with C(networks) option.

project.description: Name of the project the instance to be deployed in.

affinity_groups.description: Affinity groups names to be applied to the new instance.

security_group.description: List of security groups the instance to be applied to.

poll_async.description:
Default: True

Poll async jobs until job has finished.

cpu.description: The number of CPUs to allocate to the instance, used with custom service offerings

win_file_version.description:
Get DLL or EXE file build version
change state alway be false

path.description: File to get version(provide absolute path)

ec2_tag.description: Creates, removes and lists tags from any EC2 resource.  The resource is referenced by its resource id (e.g. an instance being i-XXXXXXX). It is designed to be used with complex args (tags), see the examples.  This module has a dependency on python-boto.

state.description:
Default: present

Whether the tags should be present or absent on the resource. Use list to interrogate the tags of an instance.

tags.description: a hash/dictionary of tags to add to the resource; '{"key":"value"}' and '{"key":"value","key":"value"}'

rds_subnet_group.description: Creates, modifies, and deletes RDS database subnet groups. This module has a dependency on python-boto >= 2.5.

subnets.description: List of subnet IDs that make up the database subnet group.

state.description:
Default: present

Specifies whether the subnet should be present or absent.

name.description: Database subnet group identifier.

description.description: Database subnet group description. Only set when a new group is added.

fetch.description: This module works like M(copy), but in reverse. It is used for fetching files from remote machines and storing them locally in a file tree, organized by hostname. Note that this module is written to transfer log files that might not be present, so a missing remote file won't be an error unless fail_on_missing is set to 'yes'.

src.description: The file on the remote system to fetch. This I(must) be a file, not a directory. Recursive fetching may be supported in a later release.

flat.description: Allows you to override the default behavior of appending hostname/path/to/file to the destination.  If dest ends with '/', it will use the basename of the source file, similar to the copy module. Obviously this is only handy if the filenames are unique.

dest.description: A directory to save the file into. For example, if the I(dest) directory is C(/backup) a I(src) file named C(/etc/profile) on host C(host.example.com), would be saved into C(/backup/host.example.com/etc/profile)

validate_md5.description:
Default: yes

Verify that the source and destination checksums match after the files are fetched.

validate_checksum.description:
Default: yes

Verify that the source and destination checksums match after the files are fetched.

fail_on_missing.description:
Default: no

Makes it fails when the source file is missing.

pushbullet.description: This module sends push notifications via Pushbullet to channels or devices.

body.description: Body of the notification, e.g. Details of the fault you're alerting.

push_type.description:
Default: note

Thing you wish to push.

device.description: The device NAME you wish to send a push notification, as seen on the Pushbullet main page.

channel.description: The channel TAG you wish to broadcast a push notification, as seen on the "My Channels" > "Edit your channel" at Pushbullet page.

device_mapping.description:
An optional list of device hashes/dictionaries with custom configurations (same block-device-mapping parameters)
Valid properties include: device_name, volume_type, size (in GB), delete_on_termination (boolean), no_device (boolean), snapshot_id, iops (for io1 volume_type)

description.description: An optional human-readable string describing the contents and purpose of the AMI.

tags.description: a dictionary of tags to add to the new image; '{"key":"value"}' and '{"key":"value","key":"value"}'

launch_permissions.description: Users and groups that should be able to launch the ami. Expects dictionary with a key of user_ids and/or group_names. user_ids should be a list of account ids. group_name should be a list of groups, "all" is the only acceptable value currently.

delete_snapshot.description:
Default: no

Whether or not to delete snapshots when deregistering AMI.

no_reboot.description: An optional flag indicating that the bundling process should not attempt to shutdown the instance before bundling. If this flag is True, the responsibility of maintaining file system integrity is left to the owner of the instance. The default choice is "no".

instance_id.description: instance id of the image to create

state.description:
Default: present

create or deregister/delete image

wait_timeout.description:
Default: 300

how long before wait gives up, in seconds

wait.description:
Default: no

wait for the AMI to be in state 'available' before returning.

name.description: The name of the new image to create

cloudtrail.description: Creates or deletes CloudTrail configuration. Ensures logging is also enabled.

aws_secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

access_key.description: AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

aws_access_key.description: AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

name.description:
name for given CloudTrail configuration.
This is a primary key and is used to identify the configuration.

region.description: The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used.

include_global_events.description: record API calls from global services such as IAM and STS?

aws_region.description: The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used.

state.description: add or remove CloudTrail configuration.

s3_bucket_prefix.description:
bucket to place CloudTrail in.
this bucket should exist and have the proper policy. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/awscloudtrail/latest/userguide/aggregating_logs_regions_bucket_policy.html)
required when state=enabled.

ec2_access_key.description: AWS access key. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

ec2_secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

s3_key_prefix.description: prefix to keys in bucket. A trailing slash is not necessary and will be removed.

ec2_region.description: The AWS region to use. If not specified then the value of the EC2_REGION environment variable, if any, is used.

os_ironic.description: Create or Remove Ironic nodes from OpenStack.

uuid.description:
Default: None

globally unique identifier (UUID) to be given to the resource. Will be auto-generated if not specified, and name is specified.
Definition of a UUID will always take precedence to a name value.

driver_info.description: Information for this server's driver. Will vary based on which driver is in use. Any sub-field which is populated will be validated during creation.

nics.description: A list of network interface cards, eg, " - mac: aa:bb:cc:aa:bb:cc"

driver.description:
Default: None

The name of the Ironic Driver to use with this node.

ironic_url.description:
Default: None

If noauth mode is utilized, this is required to be set to the endpoint URL for the Ironic API.  Use with "auth" and "auth_type" settings set to None.

state.description:
Default: present

Indicates desired state of the resource

chassis_uuid.description:
Default: None

Associate the node with a pre-defined chassis.

skip_update_of_driver_password.description: Allows the code that would assert changes to nodes to skip the update if the change is a single line consisting of the password field.  As of Kilo, by default, passwords are always masked to API requests, which means the logic as a result always attempts to re-assert the password field.

properties.description: Definition of the physical characteristics of this server, used for scheduling purposes

name.description:
Default: None

unique name identifier to be given to the resource.

lineinfile.description:
This module will search a file for a line, and ensure that it is present or absent.
This is primarily useful when you want to change a single line in a file only. See the M(replace) module if you want to change multiple, similar lines; for other cases, see the M(copy) or M(template) modules.

name.description: The file to modify.

insertbefore.description: Used with C(state=present). If specified, the line will be inserted before the last match of specified regular expression. A value is available; C(BOF) for inserting the line at the beginning of the file. If specified regular expression has no matches, the line will be inserted at the end of the file.  May not be used with C(backrefs).

dest.description: The file to modify.

create.description:
Default: no

Used with C(state=present). If specified, the file will be created if it does not already exist. By default it will fail if the file is missing.

backrefs.description:
Default: no

Used with C(state=present). If set, line can contain backreferences (both positional and named) that will get populated if the C(regexp) matches. This flag changes the operation of the module slightly; C(insertbefore) and C(insertafter) will be ignored, and if the C(regexp) doesn't match anywhere in the file, the file will be left unchanged. If the C(regexp) does match, the last matching line will be replaced by the expanded line parameter.

state.description:
Default: present

Whether the line should be there or not.

others.description: All arguments accepted by the M(file) module also work here.

insertafter.description:
Default: EOF

Used with C(state=present). If specified, the line will be inserted after the last match of specified regular expression. A special value is available; C(EOF) for inserting the line at the end of the file. If specified regular expression has no matches, EOF will be used instead. May not be used with C(backrefs).

regexp.description: The regular expression to look for in every line of the file. For C(state=present), the pattern to replace if found; only the last line found will be replaced. For C(state=absent), the pattern of the line to remove.  Uses Python regular expressions; see U(http://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html).

line.description: Required for C(state=present). The line to insert/replace into the file. If C(backrefs) is set, may contain backreferences that will get expanded with the C(regexp) capture groups if the regexp matches.

backup.description:
Default: no

Create a backup file including the timestamp information so you can get the original file back if you somehow clobbered it incorrectly.

gce_net.description: This module can create and destroy Google Compute Engine networks and firewall rules U(https://developers.google.com/compute/docs/networking). The I(name) parameter is reserved for referencing a network while the I(fwname) parameter is used to reference firewall rules. IPv4 Address ranges must be specified using the CIDR U(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_Inter-Domain_Routing) format. Full install/configuration instructions for the gce* modules can be found in the comments of ansible/test/gce_tests.py.

name.description: name of the network

src_range.description: the source IPv4 address range in CIDR notation

credentials_file.description: path to the JSON file associated with the service account email

src_tags.description: the source instance tags for creating a firewall rule

pem_file.description: path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.

state.description:
Default: present

desired state of the network or firewall

allowed.description: the protocol:ports to allow ('tcp:80' or 'tcp:80,443' or 'tcp:80-800;udp:1-25')

ipv4_range.description: the IPv4 address range in CIDR notation for the network this parameter is not mandatory when you specified existing network in name parameter, but when you create new network, this parameter is mandatory

cidr.description: the IPv4 address range in CIDR notation for the network this parameter is not mandatory when you specified existing network in name parameter, but when you create new network, this parameter is mandatory

target_tags.description: the target instance tags for creating a firewall rule

src_cidr.description: the source IPv4 address range in CIDR notation

apt_rpm.description: Manages packages with I(apt-rpm). Both low-level (I(rpm)) and high-level (I(apt-get)) package manager binaries required.

state.description:
Default: present

Indicates the desired package state

update_cache.description: update the package database first C(apt-get update).

pkg.description: name of package to install, upgrade or remove.

s3_logging.description: Manage logging facility of an s3 bucket in AWS

target_bucket.description: The bucket to log to. Required when state=present.

state.description:
Default: present

Enable or disable logging.

name.description: Name of the s3 bucket.

target_prefix.description: The prefix that should be prepended to the generated log files written to the target_bucket.

nxos_vrrp.description: Manages VRRP configuration on NX-OS switches

state.description:
Default: present

Specify desired state of the resource

interface.description: Full name of interface that is being managed for vrrp

gce.description: Creates or terminates Google Compute Engine (GCE) instances.  See U(https://cloud.google.com/products/compute-engine) for an overview. Full install/configuration instructions for the gce* modules can be found in the comments of ansible/test/gce_tests.py.

disks.description: a list of persistent disks to attach to the instance; a string value gives the name of the disk; alternatively, a dictionary value can define 'name' and 'mode' ('READ_ONLY' or 'READ_WRITE'). The first entry will be the boot disk (which must be READ_WRITE).

network.description:
Default: default

name of the network, 'default' will be used if not specified

zone.description:
Default: us-central1-a

the GCE zone to use

ip_forward.description:
Default: false

set to true if the instance can forward ip packets (useful for gateways)

external_ip.description:
Default: ephemeral

type of external ip, ephemeral by default; alternatively, a list of fixed gce ips or ip names can be given (if there is not enough specified ip, 'ephemeral' will be used)

image.description:
Default: debian-7

image string to use for the instance

service_account_permissions.description: service account permissions (see U(https://cloud.google.com/sdk/gcloud/reference/compute/instances/create), --scopes section for detailed information)

metadata.description: a hash/dictionary of custom data for the instance; '{"key":"value", ...}'

persistent_boot_disk.description:
Default: false

if set, create the instance with a persistent boot disk

pem_file.description: path to the pem file associated with the service account email This option is deprecated. Use 'credentials_file'.

instance_names.description: a comma-separated list of instance names to create or destroy

state.description:
Default: present

desired state of the resource

machine_type.description:
Default: n1-standard-1

machine type to use for the instance, use 'n1-standard-1' by default

credentials_file.description: path to the JSON file associated with the service account email

disk_auto_delete.description:
Default: true

if set boot disk will be removed after instance destruction

preemptible.description:
Default: false

if set to true, instances will be preemptible and time-limited. (requires libcloud >= 0.20.0)

tags.description: a comma-separated list of tags to associate with the instance

name.description: identifier when working with a single instance

s3.description: This module allows the user to manage S3 buckets and the objects within them. Includes support for creating and deleting both objects and buckets, retrieving objects as files or strings and generating download links. This module has a dependency on python-boto.

prefix.description: Limits the response to keys that begin with the specified prefix for list mode

marker.description: Specifies the key to start with when using list mode. Object keys are returned in alphabetical order, starting with key after the marker in order.

overwrite.description:
Default: True

Force overwrite either locally on the filesystem or remotely with the object/key. Used with PUT and GET operations. Boolean or one of [Always, Never, Different], new in 2.0

aws_secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

encrypt.description: When set for PUT mode, asks for server-side encryption

expiration.description:
Default: 600

Time limit (in seconds) for the URL generated and returned by S3/Walrus when performing a mode=put or mode=geturl operation.

retries.description: On recoverable failure, how many times to retry before actually failing.

max_keys.description:
Default: 1000

Max number of results to return in list mode, set this if you want to retrieve fewer than the default 1000 keys.

version.description: Version ID of the object inside the bucket. Can be used to get a specific version of a file if versioning is enabled in the target bucket.

s3_url.description: S3 URL endpoint for usage with Eucalypus, fakes3, etc.  Otherwise assumes AWS

metadata.description: Metadata for PUT operation, as a dictionary of 'key=value' and 'key=value,key=value'.

permission.description:
Default: private

This option lets the user set the canned permissions on the object/bucket that are created. The permissions that can be set are 'private', 'public-read', 'public-read-write', 'authenticated-read'. Multiple permissions can be specified as a list.

dest.description: The destination file path when downloading an object/key with a GET operation.

object.description: Keyname of the object inside the bucket. Can be used to create "virtual directories", see examples.

ec2_access_key.description: AWS access key id. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

ec2_secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

S3_URL.description: S3 URL endpoint for usage with Eucalypus, fakes3, etc.  Otherwise assumes AWS

access_key.description: AWS access key id. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

src.description: The source file path when performing a PUT operation.

aws_access_key.description: AWS access key id. If not set then the value of the AWS_ACCESS_KEY environment variable is used.

region.description: AWS region to create the bucket in. If not set then the value of the AWS_REGION and EC2_REGION environment variables are checked, followed by the aws_region and ec2_region settings in the Boto config file.  If none of those are set the region defaults to the S3 Location: US Standard.  Prior to ansible 1.8 this parameter could be specified but had no effect.

headers.description: Custom headers for PUT operation, as a dictionary of 'key=value' and 'key=value,key=value'.

mode.description: Switches the module behaviour between put (upload), get (download), geturl (return download url, Ansible 1.3+), getstr (download object as string (1.3+)), list (list keys, Ansible 2.0+), create (bucket), delete (bucket), and delobj (delete object, Ansible 2.0+).

secret_key.description: AWS secret key. If not set then the value of the AWS_SECRET_KEY environment variable is used.

nodeps.description: Only merge packages but not their dependencies (--nodeps)

getbinpkg.description: Prefer packages specified at PORTAGE_BINHOST in make.conf

onlydeps.description: Only merge packages' dependencies but not the packages (--onlydeps)

newuse.description: Include installed packages where USE flags have changed (--newuse)

package.description: Package atom or set, e.g. C(sys-apps/foo) or C(>foo-2.13) or C(@world)

oneshot.description: Do not add the packages to the world file (--oneshot)

update.description: Update packages to the best version available (--update)

deep.description: Consider the entire dependency tree of packages (--deep)

sync.description:
Sync package repositories first
If yes, perform "emerge --sync"
If web, perform "emerge-webrsync"

changed_use.description:
Include installed packages where USE flags have changed, except when
flags that the user has not enabled are added or removed
(--changed-use)

state.description:
Default: present

State of the package atom

usepkgonly.description: Merge only binaries (no compiling). This sets getbinpkg=yes.

depclean.description:
Remove packages not needed by explicitly merged packages (--depclean)
If no package is specified, clean up the world's dependencies
Otherwise, --depclean serves as a dependency aware version of --unmerge

pkgin.description: The standard package manager for SmartOS, but also usable on NetBSD or any OS that uses C(pkgsrc).  (Home: U(http://pkgin.net/))

upgrade.description: Upgrade main packages to their newer versions

force.description: Force package reinstall

name.description:
Name of package to install/remove;
multiple names may be given, separated by commas

full_upgrade.description: Upgrade all packages to their newer versions

state.description:
Default: present

Intended state of the package

update_cache.description: Update repository database. Can be run with other steps or on it's own.

ping.description:
A trivial test module, this module always returns C(pong) on successful contact. It does not make sense in playbooks, but it is useful from C(/usr/bin/ansible) to verify the ability to login and that a usable python is configured.
This is NOT ICMP ping, this is just a trivial test module.

route53_zone.description: Creates and deletes Route53 private and public zones

vpc_id.description: The VPC ID the zone should be a part of (if this is going to be a private zone)

state.description:
Default: True

whether or not the zone should exist or not

vpc_region.description: The VPC Region the zone should be a part of (if this is going to be a private zone)

zone.description: The DNS zone record (eg: foo.com.)

internal_dns1.description:
First internal DNS for the zone.
If not set C(dns1) will be used on C(state=present).

domain.description:
Domain the zone is related to.
Zone is a public zone if not set.

name.description: Name of the zone.

dns1.description:
First DNS for the zone.
Required if C(state=present)

internal_dns2.description: Second internal DNS for the zone.

guest_cidr_address.description: Guest CIDR address for the zone.

state.description:
Default: present

State of the zone.

dns2_ipv6.description: Second DNS for IPv6 for the zone.

network_type.description:
Default: basic

Network type of the zone.

dns1_ipv6.description: First DNS for IPv6 for the zone.

bigip_facts.description: Collect facts from F5 BIG-IP devices via iControl SOAP API

include.description: Fact category or list of categories to collect

filter.description: Shell-style glob matching string used to filter fact keys. Not applicable for software and system_info fact categories.

session.description:
Default: True

BIG-IP session support; may be useful to avoid concurrency issues in certain circumstances.

user.description: BIG-IP username

password.description: BIG-IP password

validate_certs.description:
Default: yes

If C(no), SSL certificates will not be validated. This should only be used on personally controlled sites.  Prior to 2.0, this module would always validate on python >= 2.7.9 and never validate on python <= 2.7.8

os_volume.description: Create or Remove cinder block storage volumes

image.description:
Default: None

Image name or id for boot from volume

volume_type.description:
Default: None

Volume type for volume

state.description:
Default: present

Should the resource be present or absent.

display_description.description:
Default: None

String describing the volume

snapshot_id.description:
Default: None

Volume snapshot id to create from

size.description:
Default: None

Size of volume in GB. This parameter is required when the I(state) parameter is 'present'.

async_status.description: This module gets the status of an asynchronous task.

mode.description:
Default: status

if C(status), obtain the status; if C(cleanup), clean up the async job cache located in C(~/.ansible_async/) for the specified job I(jid).

npm.description: Manage node.js packages with Node Package Manager (npm)

executable.description:
The executable location for npm.
This is useful if you are using a version manager, such as nvm

name.description: The name of a node.js library to install

state.description:
Default: present

The state of the node.js library

production.description: Install dependencies in production mode, excluding devDependencies

registry.description: The registry to install modules from.

path.description: The base path where to install the node.js libraries

set_fact.description:
This module allows setting new variables.  Variables are set on a host-by-host basis just like facts discovered by the setup module.
These variables will survive between plays during an Ansible run, but will not be saved across executions even if you use a fact cache.

key_value.description: The C(set_fact) module takes key=value pairs as variables to set in the playbook scope. Or alternatively, accepts complex arguments using the C(args:) statement.

ec2_vpc_igw.description: Manage an AWS VPC Internet gateway

vpc_id.description: The VPC ID for the VPC in which to manage the Internet Gateway.

state.description:
Default: present

Create or terminate the IGW

ec2_eni_facts.description: Gather facts about ec2 ENI interfaces in AWS

filters.description: A dict of filters to apply. Each dict item consists of a filter key and a filter value. See U(http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_DescribeNetworkInterfaces.html) for possible filters.

junos_netconf.description: This module provides an abstraction that enables and configures the netconf system service running on Junos devices.  This module can be used to easily enable the Netconf API. Netconf provides a programmatic interface for working with configuration and state resources as defined in RFC 6242.

listens_on.description:
Default: 830

This argument specifies the port the netconf service should listen on for SSH connections.  The default port as defined in RFC 6242 is 830.

state.description:
Default: present

Specifies the state of the M(junos_netconf) resource on the remote device.  If the O(state) argument is set to I(present) the netconf service will be configured.  If the O(state) argument is set to I(absent) the netconf service will be removed from the configuration.

win_ping.description: Checks management connectivity of a windows host

data.description:
Default: pong

Alternate data to return instead of 'pong'

os_server_volume.description: Attach or Detach volumes from OpenStack VM's

volume.description: Name or id of volume you want to attach to a server

device.description:
Default: None

Device you want to attach. Defaults to auto finding a device name.

state.description:
Default: present

Should the resource be present or absent.

server.description: Name or ID of server you want to attach a volume to

name.description: The path of the znode.

recursive.description: Recursively delete node and all its children.

value.description:
Default: None

The value assigned to the znode.

state.description:
Default: None

The state to enforce. Mutually exclusive with op.

timeout.description:
Default: 300

The amount of time to wait for a node to appear.

op.description:
Default: None

An operation to perform. Mutually exclusive with state.

os_object.description: Create or Delete objects and containers from OpenStack

state.description:
Default: present

Should the resource be present or absent.

container.description: The name of the container in which to create the object

name.description: Name to be give to the object. If omitted, operations will be on the entire container

container_access.description:
Default: private

desired container access level.

filename.description: Path to local file to be uploaded.

elasticache.description:
Manage cache clusters in Amazon Elasticache.
Returns information about the specified cache cluster.

engine.description:
Default: memcached

Name of the cache engine to be used.

cache_port.description:
Default: None

The port number on which each of the cache nodes will accept connections

security_group_ids.description:
Default: None

A list of vpc security group names to associate with this cache cluster. Only use if inside a vpc

name.description: The cache cluster identifier

cache_engine_version.description:
Default: None

The version number of the cache engine

node_type.description:
Default: cache.m1.small

The compute and memory capacity of the nodes in the cache cluster

parameter_group.description:
Default: None

The name of the cache parameter group to associate with this cache cluster. If this argument is omitted, the default cache parameter group for the specified engine will be used.

num_nodes.description: The initial number of cache nodes that the cache cluster will have. Required when state=present.

state.description: C(absent) or C(present) are idempotent actions that will create or destroy a cache cluster as needed. C(rebooted) will reboot the cluster, resulting in a momentary outage.

cache_security_groups.description:
Default: None

A list of cache security group names to associate with this cache cluster. Must be an empty list if inside a vpc

zone.description:
Default: None

The EC2 Availability Zone in which the cache cluster will be created

hard_modify.description: Whether to destroy and recreate an existing cache cluster if necessary in order to modify its state

cache_subnet_group.description:
Default: None

The subnet group name to associate with. Only use if inside a vpc. Required if inside a vpc

cache_parameter_group.description:
Default: None

The name of the cache parameter group to associate with this cache cluster. If this argument is omitted, the default cache parameter group for the specified engine will be used.

wait.description:
Default: True

Wait for cache cluster result before returning

azure_rm_resourcegroup.description: Create, update and delete a resource group.

state.description:
Default: present

Assert the state of the resource group. Use 'present' to create or update and 'absent' to delete. When 'absent' a resource group containing resources will not be removed unless the force option is used.

force.description: Remove a resource group and all associated resources. Use with state 'absent' to delete a resource group that contains resources.

location.description: Azure location for the resource group. Required when creating a new resource group. Cannot be changed once resource group is created.

name.description: Name of the resource group.

cloudflare_dns.description: Manages dns records via the Cloudflare API, see the docs: U(https://api.cloudflare.com/)

solo.description:
Whether the record should be the only one for that record type and record name. Only use with C(state=present)
This will delete all other records with the same record name and type.

domain.description: The name of the Zone to work with (e.g. "example.com"). The Zone must already exist.

weight.description:
Default: 1

Service weight. Required for C(type=SRV)

value.description: The record value. Required for C(state=present)

name.description:
Default: @

Record to add. Required if C(state=present). Default is C(@) (e.g. the zone name)

content.description: The record value. Required for C(state=present)

record.description:
Default: @

Record to add. Required if C(state=present). Default is C(@) (e.g. the zone name)

state.description:
Default: present

Whether the record(s) should exist or not

timeout.description:
Default: 30

Timeout for Cloudflare API calls

ttl.description:
Default: 1 (automatic)

The TTL to give the new record. Min 1 (automatic), max 2147483647

account_api_token.description: Account API token. You can obtain your API key from the bottom of the Cloudflare 'My Account' page, found here: U(https://www.cloudflare.com/a/account)

zone.description: The name of the Zone to work with (e.g. "example.com"). The Zone must already exist.

type.description: The type of DNS record to create. Required if C(state=present)

port.description: Service port. Required for C(type=SRV)

priority.description:
Default: 1

Record priority. Required for C(type=MX) and C(type=SRV)

clc_blueprint_package.description: An Ansible module to deploy blue print package on a set of servers in CenturyLink Cloud.

server_ids.description: A list of server Ids to deploy the blue print package.

package_id.description: The package id of the blue print.

wait.description:
Default: True

Whether to wait for the tasks to finish before returning.

state.description:
Default: present

Whether to install or un-install the package. Currently it supports only "present" for install action.

package_params.description: The dictionary of arguments required to deploy the blue print.

vca_nat.description: Adds or removes nat rules from a gateway in a vca environment

nat_rules.description: A list of rules to be added to the gateway, Please see examples on valid entries

purge_rules.description: If set to true, it will delete all rules in the gateway that are not given as paramter to this module.

fireball.description:
Modern SSH clients support ControlPersist which is just as fast as fireball was.  Please enable that in ansible.cfg as a replacement for fireball.
Removed in ansible 2.0.

chdir.description: cd into this directory before running make

params.description:
Default: none

Any extra parameters to pass to make

target.description:
Default: none

The target to run

jira.description: Create and modify issues in a JIRA instance.

username.description: The username to log-in with.

password.description: The password to log-in with.

description.description: The issue description, where appropriate.

fields.description: This is a free-form data structure that can contain arbitrary data. This is passed directly to the JIRA REST API (possibly after merging with other required data, as when passed to create). See examples for more information, and the JIRA REST API for the structure required for various fields.

uri.description: Base URI for the JIRA instance

project.description: The project for this operation. Required for issue creation.

assignee.description: Sets the assignee on create or transition operations. Note not all transitions will allow this.

status.description: The desired status; only relevant for the transition operation.

issuetype.description: The issue type, for issue creation.

prj.description: The project for this operation. Required for issue creation.

issue.description: An existing issue key to operate on.

hostname.description:
Set system's hostname.
Currently implemented on Debian, Ubuntu, Fedora, RedHat, openSUSE, Linaro, ScientificLinux, Arch, CentOS, AMI.
Any distribution that uses systemd as their init system.
Note, this module does *NOT* modify /etc/hosts. You need to modify it yourself using other modules like template or replace.

name.description: Name of the host

sysctl.description: This module manipulates sysctl entries and optionally performs a C(/sbin/sysctl -p) after changing them.

name.description: The dot-separated path (aka I(key)) specifying the sysctl variable.

val.description: Desired value of the sysctl key.

ignoreerrors.description: Use this option to ignore errors about unknown keys.

value.description: Desired value of the sysctl key.

reload.description:
Default: yes

If C(yes), performs a I(/sbin/sysctl -p) if the C(sysctl_file) is updated. If C(no), does not reload I(sysctl) even if the C(sysctl_file) is updated.

state.description:
Default: present

Whether the entry should be present or absent in the sysctl file.

key.description: The dot-separated path (aka I(key)) specifying the sysctl variable.

sysctl_set.description: Verify token value with the sysctl command and set with -w if necessary

sysctl_file.description:
Default: /etc/sysctl.conf

Specifies the absolute path to C(sysctl.conf), if not C(/etc/sysctl.conf).

nxos_config.description: Cisco NXOS configurations use a simple block indent file sytanx for segementing configuration into sections.  This module provides an implementation for working with NXOS configuration sections in a deterministic way.  This module works with either CLI or NXAPI transports.

force.description: The force argument instructs the module to not consider the current devices running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.

after.description: The ordered set of commands to append to the end of the command stack if a changed needs to be made.  Just like with I(before) this allows the playbook designer to append a set of commands to be executed after the command set.

lines.description: The ordered set of commands that should be configured in the section.  The commands must be the exact same commands as found in the device running-config.  Be sure to note the configuration command syntax as some commands are automatically modified by the device config parser.

replace.description:
Default: line

Instructs the module on the way to perform the configuration on the device.  If the replace argument is set to I(line) then the modified lines are pushed to the device in configuration mode.  If the replace argument is set to I(block) then the entire command block is pushed to the device in configuration mode if any line is not correct

parents.description: The ordered set of parents that uniquely identify the section the commands should be checked against.  If the parents argument is omitted, the commands are checked against the set of top level or global commands.

config.description: The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task in a playbook.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuruation to use as the base config for comparision.

match.description:
Default: line

Instructs the module on the way to perform the matching of the set of commands against the current device config.  If match is set to I(line), commands are matched line by line.  If match is set to I(strict), command lines are matched with respect to position.  Finally if match is set to I(exact), command lines must be an equal match.

before.description: The ordered set of commands to push on to the command stack if a change needs to be made.  This allows the playbook designer the opportunity to perform configuration commands prior to pushing any changes without affecting how the set of commands are matched against the system

nova_compute.description: Create or Remove virtual machines from Openstack.

availability_zone.description:
Default: None

Name of the availability zone

image_exclude.description: Text to use to filter image names, for the case, such as HP, where there are multiple image names matching the common identifying portions. image_exclude is a negative match filter - it is text that may not exist in the image name. Defaults to "(deprecated)"

flavor_include.description: Text to use to filter flavor names, for the case, such as Rackspace, where there are multiple flavors that have the same ram count. flavor_include is a positive match filter - it must exist in the flavor name.

meta.description:
Default: None

A list of key value pairs that should be provided as a metadata to the new VM

auth_url.description:
Default: http://127.0.0.1:35357/v2.0/

The keystone url for authentication

login_username.description:
Default: admin

login username to authenticate to keystone

wait_for.description:
Default: 180

The amount of time the module should wait for the VM to get into active state

security_groups.description:
Default: None

The name of the security group to which the VM should be added

scheduler_hints.description:
Default: None

Arbitrary key/value pairs to the scheduler for custom use

nics.description:
Default: None

A list of network id's to which the VM's interface should be attached

floating_ips.description:
Default: None

list of valid floating IPs that pre-exist to assign to this node

flavor_ram.description:
Default: 1

The minimum amount of ram in MB that the flavor in which the new VM has to be created must have. Mutually exclusive with flavor_id

state.description:
Default: present

Indicate desired state of the resource

auto_floating_ip.description:
Default: no

Should a floating ip be auto created and assigned

config_drive.description:
Default: no

Whether to boot the server with config drive enabled

region_name.description:
Default: None

Name of the region

key_name.description:
Default: None

The key pair name to be used when creating a VM

image_name.description:
Default: None

The name of the base image to boot. Mutually exclusive with image_id

user_data.description:
Default: None

Opaque blob of data which is made available to the instance

image_id.description:
Default: None

The id of the base image to boot. Mutually exclusive with image_name

login_password.description:
Default: yes

Password of login user

wait.description:
Default: yes

If the module should wait for the VM to be created.

name.description:
Default: None

Name that has to be given to the instance

login_tenant_name.description:
Default: yes

The tenant name of the login user

flavor_id.description:
Default: 1

The id of the flavor in which the new VM has to be created. Mutually exclusive with flavor_ram

floating_ip_pools.description:
Default: None

list of floating IP pools from which to choose a floating IP

win_webpicmd.description:
Installs packages using Web Platform Installer command-line (http://www.iis.net/learn/install/web-platform-installer/web-platform-installer-v4-command-line-webpicmdexe-rtw-release).
Must be installed and present in PATH (see win_chocolatey module; 'webpicmd' is the package name, and you must install 'lessmsi' first too)
Install IIS first (see win_feature module)

name.description: Name of the package to be installed

postgresql_privs.description:
Grant or revoke privileges on PostgreSQL database objects.
This module is basically a wrapper around most of the functionality of PostgreSQL's GRANT and REVOKE statements with detection of changes (GRANT/REVOKE I(privs) ON I(type) I(objs) TO/FROM I(roles))

objs.description:
Comma separated list of database objects to set privileges on.
If I(type) is C(table) or C(sequence), the special value C(ALL_IN_SCHEMA) can be provided instead to specify all database objects of type I(type) in the schema specified via I(schema). (This also works with PostgreSQL < 9.0.)
If I(type) is C(database), this parameter can be omitted, in which case privileges are set for the database specified via I(database).
If I(type) is I(function), colons (":") in object names will be replaced with commas (needed to specify function signatures, see examples)
Alias: I(obj)

roles.description:
Comma separated list of role (user/group) names to set permissions for.
The special value C(PUBLIC) can be provided instead to set permissions for the implicitly defined PUBLIC group.
Alias: I(role)

database.description:
Name of database to connect to.
Alias: I(db)

privs.description:
Comma separated list of privileges to grant/revoke.
Alias: I(priv)

host.description:
Database host address. If unspecified, connect via Unix socket.
Alias: I(login_host)

unix_socket.description:
Path to a Unix domain socket for local connections.
Alias: I(login_unix_socket)

state.description:
Default: present

If C(present), the specified privileges are granted, if C(absent) they are revoked.

login.description:
Default: postgres

The username to authenticate with.
Alias: I(login_user)

password.description:
The password to authenticate with.
Alias: I(login_password))

type.description:
Default: table

Type of database object to set privileges on.

port.description:
Default: 5432

Database port to connect to.

grant_option.description:
Whether C(role) may grant/revoke the specified privileges/group memberships to others.
Set to C(no) to revoke GRANT OPTION, leave unspecified to make no changes.
I(grant_option) only has an effect if I(state) is C(present).
Alias: I(admin_option)

schema.description:
Schema that contains the database objects specified via I(objs).
May only be provided if I(type) is C(table), C(sequence) or C(function). Defaults to  C(public) in these cases.

svr4pkg.description:
Manages SVR4 packages on Solaris 10 and 11.
These were the native packages on Solaris <= 10 and are available as a legacy feature in Solaris 11.
Note that this is a very basic packaging system. It will not enforce dependencies on install or remove.

category.description: Install/Remove category instead of a single package.

src.description:
Specifies the location to install the package from. Required when C(state=present).
Can be any path acceptable to the C(pkgadd) command's C(-d) option. e.g.: C(somefile.pkg), C(/dir/with/pkgs), C(http:/server/mypkgs.pkg).
If using a file or directory, they must already be accessible by the host. See the M(copy) module for a way to get them there.

name.description: Package name, e.g. C(SUNWcsr)

zone.description:
Default: all

Whether to install the package only in the current zone, or install it into all zones.
The installation into all zones works only if you are working with the global zone.

state.description:
Whether to install (C(present)), or remove (C(absent)) a package.
If the package is to be installed, then I(src) is required.
The SVR4 package system doesn't provide an upgrade operation. You need to uninstall the old, then install the new package.

proxy.description: HTTP[s] proxy to be used if C(src) is a URL.

response_file.description: Specifies the location of a response file to be used if package expects input on install. (added in Ansible 1.4)

host.description: Override local hostname (for peer probing purposes)

cluster.description: List of hosts to use for probing and brick setup

mqtt.description: Publish a message on an MQTT topic.

username.description: Username to authenticate against the broker.

payload.description: Payload. The special string C("None") may be used to send a NULL (i.e. empty) payload which is useful to simply notify with the I(topic) or to clear previously retained messages.

Default: hostname + pid

MQTT client identifier

retain.description: Setting this flag causes the broker to retain (i.e. keep) the message so that applications that subsequently subscribe to the topic can received the last retained message immediately.

mail.description:
This module is useful for sending emails from playbooks.
One may wonder why automate sending emails?  In complex environments there are from time to time processes that cannot be automated, either because you lack the authority to make it so, or because not everyone agrees to a common approach.
If you cannot automate a specific step, but the step is non-blocking, sending out an email to the responsible party to make him perform his part of the bargain is an elegant way to put the responsibility in someone else's lap.
Of course sending out a mail can be equally useful as a way to notify one or more people in a team that a specific action has been (successfully) taken.

body.description:
Default: $subject

The body of the email being sent.

username.description: If SMTP requires username

from.description:
Default: root

The email-address the mail is sent from. May contain address and phrase.

to.description:
Default: root

The email-address(es) the mail is being sent to. This is a comma-separated list, which may contain address and phrase portions.

cc.description: The email-address(es) the mail is being copied to. This is a comma-separated list, which may contain address and phrase portions.

charset.description:
Default: us-ascii

The character set of email being sent

bcc.description: The email-address(es) the mail is being 'blind' copied to. This is a comma-separated list, which may contain address and phrase portions.

port.description:
Default: 25

The mail server port

headers.description: A vertical-bar-separated list of headers which should be added to the message. Each individual header is specified as C(header=value) (see example below).

host.description:
Default: localhost

The mail server

subtype.description:
Default: plain

The minor mime type, can be either text or html. The major type is always text.

password.description: If SMTP requires password

attach.description: A space-separated list of pathnames of files to attach to the message. Attached files will have their content-type set to C(application/octet-stream).

subject.description: The subject of the email being sent.

rax_mon_alarm.description: Create or delete a Rackspace Cloud Monitoring alarm that associates an existing rax_mon_entity, rax_mon_check, and rax_mon_notification_plan with criteria that specify what conditions will trigger which levels of notifications. Rackspace monitoring module flow | rax_mon_entity -> rax_mon_check -> rax_mon_notification -> rax_mon_notification_plan -> *rax_mon_alarm*

entity_id.description: ID of the entity this alarm is attached to. May be acquired by registering the value of a rax_mon_entity task.

notification_plan_id.description: ID of the notification plan to trigger if this alarm fires. May be acquired by registering the value of a rax_mon_notification_plan task.

check_id.description: ID of the check that should be alerted on. May be acquired by registering the value of a rax_mon_check task.

label.description: Friendly name for this alarm, used to achieve idempotence. Must be a String between 1 and 255 characters long.

disabled.description: If yes, create this alarm, but leave it in an inactive state. Defaults to no.

state.description:
Default: present

Ensure that the alarm with this C(label) exists or does not exist.

criteria.description: Alarm DSL that describes alerting conditions and their output states. Must be between 1 and 16384 characters long. See http://docs.rackspace.com/cm/api/v1.0/cm-devguide/content/alerts-language.html for a reference on the alerting language.

metadata.description: Arbitrary key/value pairs to accompany the alarm. Must be a hash of String keys and values between 1 and 255 characters long.

ios_template.description: Manages Cisco IOS network device configurations over SSH.  This module allows implementors to work with the device running-config.  It provides a way to push a set of commands onto a network device by evaluting the current running-config and only pushing configuration commands that are not already configured.  The config source can be a set of commands or a template.

src.description: The path to the config source.  The source can be either a file with config or a template that will be merged during runtime.  By default the task will first search for the source file in role or playbook root folder in templates unless a full path to the file is given.

config.description: The module, by default, will connect to the remote device and retrieve the current running-config to use as a base for comparing against the contents of source.  There are times when it is not desirable to have the task get the current running-config for every task.  The I(config) argument allows the implementer to pass in the configuruation to use as the base config for comparision.

force.description: The force argument instructs the module not to consider the current device running-config.  When set to true, this will cause the module to push the contents of I(src) into the device without first checking if already configured.

backup.description: When this argument is configured true, the module will backup the running-config from the node prior to making any changes. The backup file will be written to backup_{{ hostname }} in the root of the playbook directory.

include_defaults.description: The module, by default, will collect the current device running-config to use as a base for comparision to the commands in I(src).  Setting this value to true will cause the command issued to add any necessary flags to collect all defaults as well as the device configuration.  If the destination device does not support such a flag, this argument is silently ignored.

ec2_vpc_dhcp_options.description: This module removes, or creates DHCP option sets, and can associate them to a VPC. Optionally, a new DHCP Options set can be created that converges a VPC's existing DHCP option set with values provided. When dhcp_options_id is provided, the module will 1. remove (with state='absent') 2. ensure tags are applied (if state='present' and tags are provided 3. attach it to a VPC (if state='present' and a vpc_id is provided. If any of the optional values are missing, they will either be treated as a no-op (i.e., inherit what already exists for the VPC) To remove existing options while inheriting, supply an empty value (e.g. set ntp_servers to [] if you want to remove them from the VPC's options) Most of the options should be self-explanatory.

dns_servers.description:
Default: None

A list of hosts to set the DNS servers for the VPC to. (Should be a list of IP addresses rather than host names.)

tags.description:
Default: None

Tags to be applied to a VPC options set if a new one is created, or if the resource_id is provided. (options must match)

ntp_servers.description:
Default: None

List of hosts to advertise as NTP servers for the VPC.

domain_name.description:
Default: None

The domain name to set in the DHCP option sets

delete_old.description:
Default: True

Whether to delete the old VPC DHCP option set when associating a new one. This is primarily useful for debugging/development purposes when you want to quickly roll back to the old option set. Note that this setting will be ignored, and the old DHCP option set will be preserved, if it is in use by any other VPC. (Otherwise, AWS will return an error.)

state.description:
Default: present

create/assign or remove the DHCP options. If state is set to absent, then a DHCP options set matched either by id, or tags and options will be removed if possible.

netbios_node_type.description:
Default: None

NetBIOS node type to advertise in the DHCP options. The AWS recommendation is to use 2 (when using netbios name services) http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonVPC/latest/UserGuide/VPC_DHCP_Options.html

vpc_id.description:
Default: None

VPC ID to associate with the requested DHCP option set. If no vpc id is provided, and no matching option set is found then a new DHCP option set is created.

resource_tags.description:
Default: None

Tags to be applied to a VPC options set if a new one is created, or if the resource_id is provided. (options must match)

inherit_existing.description: For any DHCP options not specified in these parameters, whether to inherit them from the options set already applied to vpc_id, or to reset them to be empty.

dhcp_options_id.description:
Default: None

The resource_id of an existing DHCP options set. If this is specified, then it will override other settings, except tags (which will be updated to match)

netbios_name_servers.description:
Default: None

List of hosts to advertise as NetBIOS servers.
